City acts on food stamps
In an attempt to force food
stamp sales at more area banks,
the Baltimore Board of Estimates
has declined to double the fee
paid to lending institutions for
the service.

Increase
The board moved unilaterally
and in the absence of Mayor
Donald
William
Schaefer
Wednesday to raise the food
stamps sales fee from 50 cents to
75 cents per transaction.
A $1 per transaction rate
sought by bankers might be
considered for approval, the
board noted, if additional stamp
sales outlets are provided.
Mayoral aide Quentin Lawson
told the board new sales outlets
and expanded service hours could
not be expected at the 50-cent
rate. He recommended SI per
transaction, a rate used in other
large cities.
Lawson advised the board that
food stamps are available in 54
locations, 37 of which are banks.

He said the administration had
sought 15 additional bank outlets
but had gotten six.
"I think the banks have us

taking
advantage
of us,"

Patty and the Baltimore connection: a dead ° legend
By RUSS SMITH
Well, another living legend has
bit the dust.
Last week's arrest of Patty
Hearst in San Francisco ended
what seemed the most perfect of
storybook kidnaps and chases. As
news of the capture flashed
across the country, showing a
handcuffed and fist-clenching
Patty, more than a few
Americans felt. just a bit
disappointed that it was all over.
The media, especially, felt
victimized by the FBI's unlikely
coup. No more weekly
summaries of Patty's alleged
activities, no more Jack Scott
denouncements of the FBI.
Probably most tragic is that we
will never read a Patty cover
story in People magazine.
After their trial, the notoriety
of the remaining SLA members
will be reduced to something
akin to the"update" section in
many periodicals. Imagine this:
"And what ever happened to
Patricia Hearst, kidnapped heiress
who denounced family and
fortune to join the Symbionese
Liberation Army back in 1974?
Today, ten years later, after
several unhappy marriages, Miss
Hearst is living on the French
Riviera, sunning by day, dancing
by night. Asked about her
involvement with the SLA, Miss
Hearst laughed heartily and said,
"Oh that? Well, for me, it was
just a fling, one of those things,
You- know how rich teenagers
always want to see the other side
of the tracks. Anyway, it was an
interesting way to live although
I wouldn't want to do it four
seasons a year. But actually,
some of it was great fun."
Yes, it's depressing that the
Patty Hearst saga is on the wane,
With only press conferences,
trials and appeals separating it
from mere history. But take
heart friends, now that Patty is in
the grips of the law there is one
final story to tell. Last spring,
when the feds were scooping up
fingerprints in an old
Pennslyvanian house, (FBI
morale was sky high, as
exchanges of fingerprints for
hard cash bonuses were being
rehearsed in each agent's mind)
Patty Hearst was quite safe and
snug, living in a seedy rowhouse
in North Baltimore.
According to local underground
figures, Patty's escape from
Pennsylvania to Baltimore was a
lesson in masterful timing,
unfolding like the best of Baby
Face Nelson's bank heists. As the
bloodhounds were sniffing out
her old hideaway, Patty was
Whisked away to the Philadelphia
train station to meet an SLA
chartered limo, scheduled to
arrive in Baltimore ninety
minutes later.
Members of the radical circle
here were overjoyed at the
Prospect of harboring the
nation's most wanted woman.
Said one radical to another,"I've
got the scene down, man, listen
1-113• Patty gets here tonight. We
meet the limo on South Charles
St., direct them to your house
Which is streaming with Welcome
Patty banners, hiding the dozens
of guests. Now I'll get the
whiskey and beer, you take care
of the chips and dip, skip the

Patty's Modest Living Quarters
pretzels and I'll tell the girls to
whip up something real nice." To
which his friend replied,"Sounds
good, man, but her name is
Tania, not Patty, Tania."
And so, Miss Hearst entered
the Baltimore underground,
draped with souvenirs and
disguises, empty bullet shells and
counterfeit dollars, all given to
her by an adoring subversive
mob. Although her modest
aparment was somewhat less
luxurious than her house in
Pennsylvania, to say nothing of

the Hearst mansion in California,
Patty felt at ease, spending long
afternoons at the Baltimore zoo,
alternately feeding cobras and
little white ducks. Nights were
filled with underground meetings
at MotherLode's Wild Cherry Pit,
which was suspiciously closed to
the public throughout the Spring.
After a few weeks of
Baltimore living, Patty shed her
necessarily reclusive lifestyle and
surged into the community,
attending neighborhood
festivities and parties. The funny

thing is that no one suspected her
dark past, giving rise to the
heroine's new boldness and
candor. She would calmly knock
on a nearby door and introduce
herself.saying,"Hello, I've just
moved to this area and am
anxious to meet all my new
neighbors. I'm Patty Hearst, who
are you?" And the neighbor
would invariably reply,"Oh, how
are you dear? Patty, such a
pretty name to go with such a
pretty girl. Come in and take
some tea and homemade pie."
One of Miss Hearst's former
neighbors, Mrs. Oscar Wertz, was
astonished when it was revealed
that Patty had been living in
Baltimore last spring. "I just had
no idea that it was her, she was
so sweet and ever so gentle. And
let me tell you, buster, I don't
care what she did on that West
coast, she'll always be the
simple, pale but beautiful girl
who enriched our lives for such a
short time."
Members of the Hopkins
Community can feel especially
silly for not noticing Patty's
presence last April, for both she
and her comrades were a part of
the Hopkins Spring Fair. Situated
on the side of Rowland Hall,
Patty and the gang manned a
handicraft booth, selling
handkerchieves and scarves, baby
booties and fishnets, all
monogrammed with the
mysterious letters SLA. And
catch this: while rowdy fairgoers
were ready to lynch the
impersonator of George Carlin,

Patty Hearst was roaming all over
the goddamn campus,
undetected!
Well, even in Baltimore a
fugitive's hour glass is bound to
run dry. When the warm weather
rolled into the City, Patty and
friends were nowhere to be
found. Since they left no
forwarding address, the
Baltimore underground, like the
rest of us, were left in the dark,
hoping that the FBI would never
catch up with them. Sadly, that
hope was snuffed out in San
Francisco, leaving eighteen
months of high adventure
unexplained.
But then, that's the stuff dead
legends are made of.

By RUSS SMITH
Well, another living legend has
bit the dust.
Last week's arrest of Patty
Hearst in San Francisco ended
what seemed the most perfect of

handcuffed and fist-clenching

Americans felt. just a bit
disappointed that it was all over.
The media, especially, felt
victimized by the FBI's unlikely
coup. No more weekly
summaries of Patty's alleged
activities, no more Jack Scott
denouncements of the FBI.
Probably most tragic is that we
will never read a Patty cover
story in People magazine.
After their trial, the notoriety
of the remaining SLA members
will be reduced to something
akin to the"update" section in
many periodicals. Imagine this:
"And what ever happened to
Patricia Hearst, kidnapped heiress
who denounced family and
fortune to join the Symbionese
Liberation Army back in 1974?
Today, ten years later, after
several unhappy marriages, Miss
Hearst is living on the French
Riviera, sunning by day, dancing
by night. Asked about her
involvement with the SLA, Miss
Hearst laughed heartily and said,
"Oh that? Well, for me, it was
just a fling, one of those things,
You- know how rich teenagers
always want to see the other side
of the tracks. Anyway, it was an
interesting way to live although
I wouldn't want to do it four
seasons a year. But actually,
some of it was great fun."
Yes, it's depressing that the
Patty Hearst saga is on the wane,
With only press conferences,
trials and appeals separating it
from mere history. But take
heart friends, now that Patty is in
the grips of the law there is one
final story to tell. Last spring,
when the feds were scooping up
fingerprints in an old
Pennslyvanian house, (FBI
morale was sky high, as
exchanges of fingerprints for
hard cash bonuses were being
rehearsed in each agent's mind)
Patty Hearst was quite safe and
snug, living in a seedy rowhouse
in North Baltimore.
According to local underground
figures, Patty's escape from
Pennsylvania to Baltimore was a
lesson in masterful timing,
unfolding like the best of Baby
Face Nelson's bank heists. As the
bloodhounds were sniffing out
her old hideaway, Patty was
Whisked away to the Philadelphia
train station to meet an SLA
chartered limo, scheduled to
arrive in Baltimore ninety
minutes later.
Members of the radical circle
here were overjoyed at the
Prospect of harboring the
nation's most wanted woman.

got the scene down, man, listen

whip up something real nice." To
which his friend replied,"Sounds
good, man, but her name is
Tania, not Patty, Tania."
And so, Miss Hearst entered
the Baltimore underground,
draped with souvenirs and
disguises, empty bullet shells and

mob. Although her modest

This Saturday at 2:00 p.m. the
Hopkins football team will take
the field for the first time,
opening the 1975 season against
MAC rivals, the Muhlenberg
Mules at home on Homewood
Field.
Where as this will be the Blue
Jays' opening game, the Mules
already have one contest under
their belts. Last weekend, the
Pennsylvanians
opened
by
completely demolishing Western
Maryland 41-0. Based on the
conference games held last
weekend the Mules are leading
the Southern Division of the
MAC in both total offense, with
623 years and in total defense by
holding the Green Terrors to 283
yards.
Muhlenberg
quarterback,
four-year starter Mike Reid has
always been one of the top
signal-callers in the MAC. Last
week against Western Maryland,
Reid completed 15 of 22 passes
including two scoring tosses to
his ace receivers Staehle and
Christian.
Mules are more effective on
the ground than in the air and
Muhlenberg proved that also last
week placing their _top three
rushers, John Mill, Leland Lott,
and Jerry Fahy in the 1-2-3 slots
in the MAC individual rushing
stats.
On the ground or in the air,
the Muhlenberg offense is going
to be a tough test for the green
Hopkins defense. A great deal of
that pressure will rest on senior

linebackers Wayne Panullo and
John Nutting to halt that
awesome Mule rushing attack.
The Homewood offensive unit
will not escape unscathed either.
After showing a great deal of
improvement in last weekend's
scrimmage at Georgetown, the
offense will face the task of
moving the ball against a strong

Muhlenberg defense which is
spearheaded by safetyman and
co-captain
Bill
Ray
and
All-Conference defensive end,
Tom Smyers.
Another factor working to the
disadvantage of the Jays is the
weather. Due to the rain, the
Hopkins eleven has been unable
to work on polishing up their

plays as much as they would have
liked
this
week,
while
Muhlenberg last week gained
valuable game experience.
Last year, Hopkins defeated
Muhlenberg 9-0 in a mud-bath
played on the Mules home
stomping grounds. In the overall
series between the two teams,
Hopkins holds a four game to

three edge.
"We are going to face a very
tough game," noted Hopkins
Coach Dennis Cox grimly. "In
order to win we are going to have
to control the ball offensively.
By keeping the ball away from
them they will be unable to
score. And on the de fense,we
